'''Kitty Brown''' was an [[United States|American]] [[classic female blues]] singer. She sometimes used the [[pseudonym]]s of Bessie Williams (although she was not alone in using this name), Jane White, Dixie Gray, Rosa Green and Mazie Leroy.<ref name="AMG"/> Brown was active as a recording artist from 1923 to the mid-1930s. Her best known tracks were "I Wanna Jazz Some More" and "[[It's De-Lovely]]". Little is known of her life outside of her music.

==Career==
The bulk of Brown's recording work occurred in 1923 and 1924, although in the 1930s she waxed one track, with [[Les Brown (bandleader)|Les Brown]]'s Band of Renown. It was a working of [[Cole Porter]]'s song, "[[It's De-Lovely]]".<ref name="AMG"/>

The title of her 1924 track, "I Wanna Jazz Some More", is misleading.  The word 'jazz' was used as a euphemism for bodily fluid, and not as a reference to the musical art form.  In the manner of the time, several of Brown's songs used [[Innuendo|sexual innuendo]], but not all her tracks were similarly slanted.  It is also probable that contractual agreements with [[record label]]s saw her record elsewhere under a number of assumed names, some of which are difficult to verify.<ref name="AMG"/>

Her debut session produced the songs "Evil Blues" and "Mean Eyes (Too Late Blues)".  The former track had the notation accompanied by Rickett Stars, almost certainly another stage name. Her main musical partner was the [[songwriter]] LeRoy Morton, who also acted as manager for [[Clara Smith]]. On the [[Okeh Records|Okeh]] label, Brown and Morton recorded "He's Never Gonna Throw Me Down" and "Keep on Going". One of her later recording pseudonyms, Mazie Leroy, might have connections to the association with him.<ref name="AMG">{{cite web |first= |last= |url={{Allmusic|class=artist|id=p543366/biography|pure_url=yes}} |title=Biography by Eugene Chadbourne |publisher=Allmusic.com |accessdate=September 30, 2011}}</ref> As was becoming more common then, much of Brown's material came via the music publishing arm of her record label.  A later session saw her record "Family Skeleton Blues", one of her more beguiling sides.<ref name="AMG"/> Amongst her accompanists was [[James "Bubber" Miley]].<ref>{{cite book
| first= A. H.
| last= Lawrence
| year= 2001
| title= Duke Ellington and His World
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Roudedge 
| location= London
| isbn= 0-415-93012-X
| page= 28}}</ref>

The amount of recording she undertook under various other names, probably exceeds output under her own.<ref name="AMG"/> Verification is made more difficult, as the name of Bessie Williams was used by several singers.<ref>{{cite book
| first= Ross
| last= Laird
| year= 1996
| title= Moanin' Low: a discography of female popular vocal recordings, 1920-1933
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Greenwood Press 
| location= Westport, Connecticut
| isbn= 0-313-29241-8
| page= 583}}</ref> However, Brown has been certified as the singer on several songs released on the [[Domino Records (before 1993)|Domino]] label, despite them being billed as Williams.<ref name="AMG"/>

The bulk of her known work was included on the [[compilation album]], ''Female Blues Singers, Vol. 3: B/C (1923-1928)'' made available in 1997 by [[Document Records]].<ref name="Comp">{{cite web|url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r259118/credits|pure_url=yes}} |title=Allmusic ((( ''Female Blues Singers, Vol. 3: B/C (1923-1928)'' > Credits )))}}</ref> Her sides included the songs, "Evil Blues", "Mean Eyes (Too Late Blues)", "Deceitful Blues", "I Don't Let No One Man Worry Me", "He's Never Gonna Throw Me Down", "Keep on Going", "Family Skeleton Blues", "I Wanna Jazz Some More", "Keep On Going" and "One Of These Days".<ref>{{cite book
| first= Ross
| last= Laird
| year= 1996
| title= Moanin' Low: a discography of female popular vocal recordings, 1920-1933
| edition= 1st
| publisher= Greenwood Press 
| location= Westport, Connecticut
| isbn= 0-313-29241-8
| pages= 56/7}}</ref>
